ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned all about the Arabian Nights tradition, which is a fascinating part of world literature. This class was great at varying work, and we constantly engaged in the material in many ways, watching movies, reading short stories inspired by the Nights, and doing group creative projects.

I learned a lot about the history of the Arabian Nights and story telling as a whole. It was really interesting to see how stories get translated and adapted into different formats and for different audiences.
Read fascinating stories from the Nights and studied its adaptations/translations
So fun! Learned about important work of literature and how its permeated society!
I developed the ability to critically consider literary works and their histories that shaped how the world perceives them.
I developed my close reading skills quite a bit in this course. Also, I gained many insights into the relationship between Arabic literature and Western culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was especially good at varying work: there was a constant stream of assignments but it was never overwhelming and the content was super interesting. I would say a weakness is if you're looking for more of a seminar set up: Professor Creswell usually lectures for part of the class and only part of the class is discussion so it's good to keep that in mind.

strength = had a lot of different themes, so there was something for everyone
cons = the class was a little large, so class discussion was a little repressed

Strengths: great readings, engaging discussions, and a very manageable workload (always w/ opportunities for creative assignments!) The only weakness I could think of was that I wish we did more ice breakers/activities to bond as a class-- All the students were great, and I only wish we were closer

The Arabian Nights is a fascinating reading experience, and I was able to appreciate the tales so much more thanks to themes we discussed in class. Although I loved the source material, the class was run slightly more like a lecture (with occasional questions and comments from students) than a seminar. Perhaps that's because the class size tends to be larger than for other English courses. I would have enjoyed the course more if each class were more structured, perhaps with a 20-minute lecture at the beginning and then the rest of the time reserved for discussion.
Such a fun course! The readings varied a lot in length. Streamlining may help.
The course was fun and engaging, and I learned a lot about the Arabian Nights.

The strengths of the course include the course content and content of the assignments. Weaknesses included the lengths of the assignments which sometimes caused me and other students to sacrifice one portion of the readings/assignments for another.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes definitely! The Nights are so fun and it's great to really dive into one topic for a whole semester.
YES! so interesting and professor Creswell is very nice, understanding and knowledgeable. he always presents a new and interesting take on the readings.
YES! This class is absolutely delightful and there are many opportunities to creatively approach the texts. We had some great guest speakers come in too!

Yesthe "work" I did for this class never really felt like work. The stories are fascinating and wildly different from the types of literature you encounter in other English classes. Rather than write traditional essays, you get to write 3-4 short "thought papers" that are only two pages each and don't require a formal thesis statement; they're genuinely fun ways to engage with the material. The class does border on being a lecture at times, so if you prefer seminars for English courses this may not be the best choice.
YES! So fun! And Professor Creswell is amazing!
I would recommend it to other students who are interested in the subject.
Absolutely. Anyone interested in The Arabian Nights can take this course and have a wonderful time with it.
